Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Consequences of sympatry and allopatry for variation in reproductive genes of Drosophila pseudoobscura
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many factors influence mate choice in both plants and animals, including choosing a mate that will provide the best quality offspring while avoiding individuals of different species. The integration of these factors into a single choice implies that traits involved in mate selection within species could be the same traits that cause species to diverge from one another. Recently, the investigators used genetically modified Drosophila melanogaster to show that the same genes that control within species mate choice are also involved in species discrimination. This project is testing this association in a natural system, to understand how different populations accumulate changes in genes that control mate choice and species discrimination. These data will provide insight into the molecular mechanisms underlying natural variation in mate choice and the formation of reproductively isolated populations, which are important factors in understanding how new species arise over evolutionary time.

The proposed research will examine DNA sequence and gene expression variation in reproductive genes in natural populations of the fruit fly Drosophila pseudoobscura, using high depth nucleotide sequencing. The experiment contrasts genetic changes that have occurred in populations that co-occur with closely related species, and thus must discriminate against them during mate choice, with changes in populations that are not exposed to other species. Analyses will assess genetic variation across all reproductive genes, as well as specifically in genes known to affect gamete competition. These variants will be associated with phenotypic data on mate choice within and between species, to differentiate genes that are important to mate choice, to species discrimination, and to both reproductive behaviors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many factors influence mate choice in both plants and animals, including choosing a mate that will provide the best quality offspring while avoiding individuals of different species. The integration of these factors into a single choice implies that traits involved in mate selection within species could be the same traits that cause species to diverge from one another. The investigators initially used genetically modified Drosophila melanogaster to show that the same genes that control within species mate choice are also involved in species discrimination. The funded research used a natural system to understand how different populations accumulate changes in genes that control both species mate choice and species discrimination, in order to examine the consequences of the same genes having functions in both, of these behaviors. These data provide insight into the molecular mechanisms underlying natural variation in mate choice and the formation of reproductively isolated populations.

The funded research examined DNA sequence and gene expression variation in reproductive genes in natural populations of the fruit fly D. pseudoobscura, using high depth nucleotide sequencing. Twenty-eight distinct genotypes were sequenced for both male and female individuals (56 samples in total). The research contrasted genetic changes that have occurred in populations that co-occur with closely related species, and thus must discriminate against them during mate choice, with changes in populations that are not exposed to other species. A significant finding was that mate discrimination has acted on sperm competition in populations of D. pseudoobscura that co-occur with a closely related species. In particular, sperm competitive ability against another species has been strengthened, whereas competitive ability against males of the same population has been weakened. This is a novel demonstration that optimization of these two behaviors might trade-off against each other, because they share underlying genes. Ongoing analyses of DNA sequence and gene expression variation across all reproductive genes have found significant differences between populations, including at genes that are necessary for spermatogenesis and sperm motility. In addition, we have found differences in genes that encode components of seminal fluid that are known to influence patterns of sperm usage, and therefore competition, in other Drosophila species. In future, these variants will be associated with phenotypic data on mate choice within and between species, to further differentiate genes that are important to mate choice, to species discrimination, and to both reproductive behaviors.

These data and all tools used in their analysis will be made publicly available as a detailed transcriptomic dataset for the evolutionary genetics and reproductive biology research communities. The funded research also directly contributed to development and training of one graduate student and two undergraduate students, including training in experimental design, molecular biology (RNA extraction, RNA quantification), and bioinformatics analysis. Both undergraduates have since matriculated and are pursuing advanced degrees in medical fields. The graduate student received additional advanced training in computational resource development, data handling, and analysis. Since completion of the granting period, the graduate student has matriculated with his PhD and now holds a postdoctoral position at Cornell University, funded by a competitive National Institutes of Health-NRSA Individual Postdoctoral Fellowship.
